section.title: Reading Assignment
section.p: Read Sections 10.1 and 10.2 of Applied Discrete Structures. In these sections we introduce trees, which are connected graphs without cycles. We also examine spanning trees of connected graphs, which are the smallest subgraphs which maintain connectedness in a graph.

statement.p: In general, a family tree isn't really a tree in the sense of graph theory. Explain why. You can assume links in the family tree are undirected.

section.p: Also, turn in solutions to these exercises:

statement.p: Given a tree with n vertices, n \geq 2, how many leaves (vertices of degree 1) could it have?
What can you say about the sum of the entries in the degree sequence of a tree?
Use the planarity of trees together with to derive the relationship between the number of vertices and number of edges in a tree.
Prove that every tree is bipartite, i. e., has a 2-coloring.
Prove that the center of any tree can have no more than two vertices.

solution.p: If we can prove that any two vertices in the center of a tree must be adjacent, then having three or more vertices in the center would violate the acyclic property of a tree.

Suppose v_1 and v_2 belong to the center a tree. Furthermore assume they have eccentricity k and that they are not adjacent; so there is a vertex w l in the path between them. (Recall that paths between vertices in a tree are unique.) Since the eccentricity of v_1 is k there must be a vertex u whose (edge) distance from v_1 is k. The path between them must pass through v_2l for otherwise, the distance from u to v_2 would be greater than k which is a contradiction. This means that the distance from w to u is less than k. We can apply this logic to any vertex whose disance from either v_i is equal to k and conclude that the eccentricity of w is less than the radius of the tree, which is a contradiction.

statement.p: Prove that every connected graph which is not itself a tree must have at last three different spanning trees.
Use Prim's algorithm starting at vertex 1 to find a minimal spanning tree for the following graph.

image.description: A weighted undirected graph on 10 vertices. The edges are are given by the list of triples [[1,2,8],[1,5,6],[1,9,7],[1,10,10],[3,5,11],[3,7,9],[4,9,13],[5,8,12],[6,7,5],[6,10,13]], where the first two entries are the vertices of the edge and the last entry is its weight.

solution.p: The edges that are added, in order are {1,5}, {1,9}, {1,2},{9,7}, {7,6},{7,3},{1,10},{5,8},{9,4}. This assumes that if there is a tie in possibly adding an edge, the smallest vertex number is added, which is the case when {1,2} is added.
